content: today we're going to talk about hobbying
safely
hey guys welcome back to black magic craft today we're going to talk about
hobbying safely our hobby is a pretty safe one
there's not a lot you have to do to protect yourself i like all my friends
get constantly bombarded with comments about
you should do x y z this that or the other
thing because you're not being safe usually it's like why aren't you wearing
a mask or glasses or whatever but recently i received a lot of
comments about why was i wearing a mask while
doing a particular task i was doing something that
was kind of a basic safety measure that everyone should do and a fair bit of
people couldn't figure out why i was wearing a mask
in that situation so made me realize this time we had another talk about
safety i did a video about safety very early on in this channel's history
and i think i was a little bit kind of a little bit negligent in that video i
didn't take it seriously enough but i'm a little bit older
a little bit wiser a little bit more health conscious and i realize
a lot more the impact and responsibility i have
on my viewers i need to actually take a minute to properly address some very
basic safety things and show how i keep myself
healthy while doing this wonderful hobby now all
the items that i use all the ppe to keep myself safe while hobbying i
will put some links in the video description where you
can pick them up also most of this stuff is listed on my essential equipment page
on blackmagicraft.ca along with all the other
stuff that i usually use to hop so be sure to check that out where are we
going to start cutting this is a common one constantly
get people saying oh don't cut towards yourself
you're so dangerous terrible knife use blah blah blah
blah blah do not cut towards yourself that's a general
kind of idiot proof rule about using a knife and it's a it's a decent enough
rule if you don't understand how to use a knife
safely just know one thing don't cut towards yourself and you should be fine
that being said there are many situations where you can very safely cut
towards yourself in a very controlled manner watch a chef peel an apple or a
potato and they will be cutting towards
themselves much like i will often cut towards myself but the really
important thing is that i'm using a sharp blade it's the correct blade for
the task i am not forcing it through the material
if i'm cutting towards a finger or something
i'm doing so very carefully very slowly and with very little force so that if i
were to slip it's not going to come at me with a
lot of force and cause a serious injury i'm hyper aware of knowing the
trajectory of my blade and the severity of the cut
that i may receive if something slips it's all about risk
assessment it's about knowing how bad things could
go every cut you do you should be aware of
the worst possible outcome and make an informed decision about whether or
not it's safe i'm not going to be cutting through
solid wood with a knife that requires a lot of force
you shouldn't do that anyway but if i am i'm not going to do that towards me
because i know that if i'm putting a lot of pressure
and force and if i slip it's going to come at me real hard and be real
dangerous but i'm cutting a little bit of foams
carefully and slowly i'm not too worried about it
because i know if i slip it's not going to be a big deal for the
most part don't cut towards yourself but if you're comfortable with your
tools you know how to use them properly and you can correctly assess the risk
then you know make in smart decisions just
use some common sense but when in doubt don't cut towards yourself
don't throw these blades in the trash if you got kids in the house especially
they might put their hands in the garbage to get something and you don't
want them stabbing themselves but even yourself
i mean i constantly am throwing stuff in my garbage
can when it's getting a little bit full what do you do you
push it down you got random blades in there
you will eventually hurt yourself and i know that from experience
so what i like to do is keep a spare container this is just an old empty
container from knife blades you can use a jar
whatever it doesn't really matter essentially it's just a sharps container
where you put all your old blades that keeps them
all together when this is full you can throw it in the trash and if you want to
be really kind to your waste collectors in your city
you can also tape this up before throwing it in
now let's talk about gloves you never in our hobby need any kind of
serious gloves but it is a good idea to have
some nitrile gloves on hand avoid latex gloves they are permeable by
many things and you can also develop a latex allergy
using them long term these are going to keep your hands clean
and safe while hobbying you only really need to use these when you're dealing
with certain chemicals if you're dealing with
epoxy resins five-minute epoxy that sort of stuff
it's a good idea to wear these gloves one because you don't want that stuff
on your skin because once it's dry it's the
bugger to get off but also because you don't want those things absorbing
into your skin one thing about your skin is that
things absorb into it painting is another time where you want to be
wearing these gloves now when you're just painting miniatures
or whatever with a brush it's not a big deal but if you
are airbrushing or rattle can spraying you definitely want to be wearing these
gloves especially like aerosol enamel paint or whatever getting onto
your skin again pain in the butt to clean off but that
will absorb into your skin and i'm not a doctor i'm
not a scientist but i don't think having these chemicals absorbed into your
bloodstream is healthy for anyone so why not avoid
it you spray paint a couple things in your lifetime once or twice yeah
i'm assuming the harm it's causing is going to be pretty
negligible i mean if you're spray painting or airbrushing often
i i don't know what those long term effects are going to be
with paint absorption on into your body on an almost daily basis so
some simple gloves are just going to solve that problem
and keep your hands clean and if you do 3d printing if you're working with resin
you also want to be wearing gloves that resin you certainly don't want going
into your skin it can also cause allergic reactions in
certain people it can cause some pretty serious burns
on your skin so wear gloves it's a really simple
thing plus you can like feel cool wearing these
black rubber gloves which leads me to my next thing which is safety glasses these
are very important and something i think a lot of people neglect when you're
using something like a rotary tool these are great for
sanding for drilling all sorts of hobby things you want to wear glasses because
you don't want little shards of things getting into your eyes when i was a
contractor a carpenter i once got a very very very small
piece of sawdust in my eye that ended up scratching my cornea
and if you've ever had a scratched cornea you know
it's something you want to avoid you got to go to the hospital you got to get
this dye put in your eye where they see it
then you got to wear get it flushed out wear an eye patch
you can go blind like it's nasty it made me really respect
safety glasses and their importance you don't just need them when you're
operating power tools you might need it when doing very simple
things for example when i'm cleaning resin prints and i'm just
very carefully with a knife cleaning stuff off the prints or even
cleaning mold lines off of models i wear glasses because it's really easy for a
little particle to go right into your eyeball and cause you
all sorts of problems when you're working with resin and a 3d printer and
you're pouring if you're working with alcohol you're mixing epoxies whatever
you want to wear glasses because it's really easy for those things to splash
and flick up and get you in the eyeballs and you just
don't want crap getting in your eyeballs keep your
eyeballs safe let's take a quick minute to talk about
the sponsor of this video skillshare is an online learning
community with thousands of classes for creative and curious people like
yourself they offer a variety of classes designed to keep you inspired and help
you express yourself many classes are focused on art and could easily be
applied to our hobby like painting and color theory if you've
been considering starting your own hobby channel but don't know where to start
when it comes to filming editing graphic design or any of the other skill
sets involved in creating content well this is about the absolute best
place you can go to learn about those things with so much going on in the
world today having more content creators sharing their voice and passion is
more valuable than ever my friend jazza has a few classes that can help you get
going as a hobby content creator is how to talk and present to camera
like a pro series will help you get comfortable in front of a
camera personally i'm pretty comfortable with talking to a camera at this point
but i'm terrible at drawing so i'm more
interested in learning to draw with his mastering illustration
sketching inking and color essentials class
with so many classes to explore skillshare is going to empower you to
express yourself with the help of a community of
millions of creatives because their videos are curated specifically for
education you won't have any outside distractions like ads
making it difficult to focus at less than ten dollars a month with an annual
subscription skillshare is affordable and a worthwhile investment for
self-development the first 1000 of my subscribers to
click the link in the video description we'll get a two-month
free trial of premium membership so you can explore your creativity thanks
skillshare for helping creative people develop their passions and for
sponsoring this video styrofoam xps foam eps foam whatever
foam you're using if you are sanding it and creating
any amount of dust those fine particulates of styrofoam dust are going
to float into the air and if you're breathing that air it's
going to get into your lungs and the thing about styrofoam is that it
doesn't break down you don't really want any debris or
material in your lungs if possible but something like styrofoam that's not
an organ organic material it's not gonna break
down you're gonna have little particulate of styrofoam dust in your
lungs forever what are the health effects of that i
don't know stands to reason that they're not
it's not good if you're doing a task that creates very very small amount of
styrofoam dust in the air but you do it a hundred times well that
adds up to being a fair amount of dust so i wear a mask
for this i just wear a dust mask this one is kind of
a fancier cooler looking one with filters that you can remove
and change it has a little bit of activated carbon filters that help with
smell and all that this is the kind of thing that
you'd want to be wearing while riding your bike
in a polluted or dusty place but it's also great
for when you're doing dusty things in your hobby
you can use just a paper mask a handkerchief
whatever just something to keep dust out it doesn't deal with
vapors or chemicals or anything like that just dust
i also use this mask when i'm mixing something like sculpta mold
or some kind of plaster because again when you pour that
that really fine powder is going to get up into the air and you're going to
breathe it in and think about something like plaster
do you want to breathe in plaster dust that gets into your lungs and then is
activated by moisture and hardens into plaster
again i don't know the medical effects of that but i don't want to find out
this is also the mask that i wear when i'm airbrushing now i have a spray booth
which i'll talk about in a second and it does 90 of the work for getting
all the dust particulates out of the room and out of my space
but it's not 100 effective there's still fine particles of
paint dust that come up and when i'm working right there
i don't want to be breathing it in so i wear this mask for that
task even sometimes when i'm outside spray painting i will wear this mask
just in case because why not it's easy and it
there's no harm in wearing it if you are spray painting
or working with any kind of chemicals resin or epoxies
things that might off gas that's not going to help you're going to actually
need a respirator and you want something that
filters organic vapors so you're going to find a respirator like this
it's got to be close fitting and have the appropriate filters so this is what
you want to wear when you're spray painting
and in an enclosed space although you shouldn't be spray painting in an
enclosed space go outside or use a spray booth i use this
all the time when i'm mixing chemicals when i mixed my clear resin
for my tiger monk and it had that crazy chemical reaction you could hear me
breathing kind of heavily that's because i was
wearing this mask because i don't know what's off gassing
when working with those chemicals i play it safe
and i wear my respirator this is also the kind of thing
that you might want to wear if you're using a hot wire
cutter cutting styrofoam in a place that has poor air circulation and you're
concerned about the fumes from that this can help with the hot wire like
a lot of things you want to ensure you do have good
ventilation i airbrush inside but i use a spray booth and my spray booth
has a really powerful inline fan i have a whole video about building the
spray booth that covers everything about that
and that's what i use to suck all of the vapors and
particulates of paint dust out of my room when i'm
painting i also can disconnect the hose from it
and connect it to my 3d printer to run the fan on very low
to suck all the resin fumes out of my space when the printer is
operating and stirring the resin up what's nice is that i can also
disconnect that hose and direct it to my workbench and turn
the fan on full blast and that's going to suck out fumes from my hot wire table
dust if i'm sanding foam or using plaster or whatever
i still am going to wear my mask but it's going to suck out a lot of it and
pump it outside you may not have that option i
mean getting a fan and cutting a hole in your
wall and pumping it outside or even putting it through a window is a bit of
an investment and that may not be feasible but you
should still be thinking about good air circulation and venting and it may
be as simple as opening up a window and taking a fan and
blowing it and pushing all the bad stuff out towards
that way if your window's over here you're working here put your fan over
here and it's going to blow things past you and away from you and go
outside something like your hot wire table the
fumes on it as far as i understand are fairly innocent as long as you're
not burning and combusting the foam and command
and creating black smoke the white smoke is mostly water vapor
and from all the information i can find it's mostly harmless
but to be honest i've tried to find a really concrete evidence that i could
bring to you guys and say it is safe here's a scientist
saying it but i've actually found that very
challenging to do so i don't want to say it's totally safe
and you should definitely be using your hot wire and foam in a well ventilated
area do it outside if you have to do it near a window use a fan blowing
stuff away from you use an extraction fan if you can just do
something and if you really have to wear a mask
that's rated for organic vapors now even with
all of that wearing the mask and having extraction
fans i found that over the past year or so i've
had some irritation in my throat and my nasal cavity always
feeling like i'm having a sinus infection and that's
new to me i never experienced that in life even when i was working as a
contractor in very dusty dirty environments and not necessarily being
that safe and with the whole coronavirus thing you
know you start to be more aware of every tickle in your throat and every
sore throat and i started to realize that
it would happen when i spent long periods of time working
in this room in this environment and i don't know if it's just the residual
dust from various things i mean with my bright lights i
can really see the dust floating around i don't know if it's
maybe from the resin but something was irritating me i knew i
had to do something on top of everything else to just
improve the air quality in my room so i looked into a hepa filter
it's just a little machine that sucks the air in
filters it and pumps out clean air i bought one i actually did notice a
difference maybe it's a placebo but since running
it i've noticed an improvement in that you know feeling in
my throat and nasal cavity it hasn't been back and the one that i
bought is great because it actually has an auto feature that tests the air
quality and it kicks in higher or lower depending on
what's needed it's allowed me to see what situations the air quality
in my room degrades i have it set up right next to my spray booth and it kind
of shows me how well my spray booth is working
i can spray paint a lot airbrush a lot in there and the
hepa filter still reads as good air quality but if i
spray too much for too long of a period or if i forget to turn the fan on
my hepa filter instantly goes red indicates bad air quality
and pumps into high gear filtering that out it's sort of proven to me how
effective this spray booth actually is because it shows me that when i'm not
using it or if i forget to connect the hose to it or i have it too low
the hepa filter tells me hey man air quality
it's getting it's getting not good and it also shows me that it's working when
it's working so that's kind of the thing you can do if you're concerned
maybe you live in an apartment and you don't have an option to build a big
spray booth you could consider getting a hepa filter and
that will help with the quality of the ambient
air in your room when you're doing various things so wearing your mask
while doing it should help protect you while you're
doing it and the hepa filter can help clean the air out so that you can
take your mask off and have a clean livable space that's all i can really
think to cover because like i said our hobby is not that dangerous you want to
protect your eyes protect your lungs don't cut yourself by doing something
really stupid you can follow those things you'll
probably be safe i wouldn't lose too much sleep about the
dangers of our hobby but it would take some time to
protect yourself and don't just go off of what i'm saying here i'm just a guy
who's sharing my personal experience i am not a health and safety expert
i have no training that makes what i'm saying
uh official in any way use some common sense
spend some time reading things reading warning labels on the products you use
just use some common sense i hope that you found this video helpful and i hope
that didn't scare you too much i hope that it just
made you think a little bit and be a little bit more responsible
if you enjoyed this video hit that like button and let me know in the comments
section below if you have any really valuable safety
tips that i maybe forgot because i'm sure there's many
feel free to post them in the comments don't forget to check out my essential
equipment page on blackmagiccraft.ca or the video description for links on
where to buy the stuff that you might need to hobby safely
and if you really enjoy these videos that i make consider supporting the
channel on patreon it's through the funds there
that i'm able to dedicate my time and efforts into making
these videos and the equipment that's required i'd love to have you as
the newest member of the black magic craft fellowship
that's it for this week guys thanks for watching
